section.p: This document attempts to describe what the default keymaps do for the terminal types covered in the Kermit 95 Control Sequences manual. This includes the default keybindings for each terminal type, and information about any referenced keyverbs.

Prior to Kermit 95 v3.0 beta.8 there was no documentation that covered what various keys and keyverbs sent, only what they were. This document was produced by reading through all the kverb handling code and recording the responses they sent based on the varous terminal types. The keymap tables were generated by a script from default.ksc.

section.title: Default Key Map
section.p: Kermit 95 includes keymaps suitable for each of the terminals it emulates. These keymaps specify what each key on the keyboard does; many keys just send themselves (the 'a' key sends ascii character \{98}, 'a'), while others may send either special Keyboard Verbs whose definition may vary based on the current terminal type, or literal text including control sequences.

In key definitions, where you see notation such as \{98}, that means send character 98 (decimal), which in this case is 'a'. You'll see \{27} (ESC) appear when a key (or keyboard verb) sends an escape sequence, for example.

In addition to the terminal-specific keymaps shown int he table below (which can be modified with SET TERMINAL KEY), there are the additional Special Keyboard Modes which act as an overlay to modify the underlying terminal-specific keymap or user key definitions.
For the full details, see the Key Mapping section of the users guide.

section.title: Keymaps for Special Keyboard Modes
section.p: In addition to terminal-type specific keymaps, Kermit 95 has Special Keyboard Modes. When one of these is enabled, it acts as an overlay changing specific key definitions to be more suitable for a particular application or language:
Any key not defined by the current special keyboard mode, will fall through to the user key definitions, or the terminal-type-specific keymap.

section.title: Keyboard Verbs
section.hide-badges: qnx ibm31 vc4404 adm3a adm5 hzl1500 vc4404 vtnt xterm tek40
section.p: Keyboard Verbs (kverbs) do something. They might perform some action within kermit such as searching in the scrollback buffer, jumping to bookmarks, switching to command mode, etc. Or they might send something to the remote host.

When they appear in key maps, KVerbs start with \K to indicate that they're a kverb and not something else. Only those KVerbs that appear in the keymaps in earlier sections are covered below; for a full list of all kverbs and what they do, see the Kermit 95 users guide.
Strings sent by are given in C-Kermits notation: \{27} is character 27, \\ is is the '\' character, etc.

section.title: Back Search Next
section.p: Next instance of search string backwards

section.title: Toggle Terminal Debugging
section.p: Toggles terminal debugging mode (SET TERM DEBUG). When ON, shows control characters rather than acting on them.

section.title: Toggle debug log file
section.p: Toggles logging to the debug log file (debug.log by default)

section.title: Home key on PC keyboard on VT520
Down Arrow
section.p: If the current terminal type is NOT one of those specially indicated below, K95 sends: \{27}B
Sends one of the following (can be changed via udfkeys):
Sends LF: \{10} (can be changed via udfkeys)
Sends SYN: \{22} (can be changed via udfkeys)
Sends one of the following depending on the SET TERM ARROW setting

section.title: Command Shell
section.p: Opens the default shell. In the OS/2 and windows console versions of Kermit 95, this will take over the console window and you must exit the shell to return to Kermit 95.
In the Windows GUI version of Kermit 95 (k95g.exe), the shell will open in a new window. You must close the shell window to return to Kermit 95.

section.title: Print Current Screen
section.p: Dumps current screen text to the SET PRINTER device.

section.title: End Screen
section.p: Go to the bottom of the buffer.

section.title: Exit Terminal Mode
section.p: Exits terminal mode and returns to the command screen. To return to the terminal, type connect.

section.title: Reverse Foreground and Background Colors
section.p: Flips the foreground and background colors

section.title: Display function key labels
section.p: Displays function key labels in HP and WYSE emulations

section.title: Continue forward search
section.p: For searching in the buffer, continues to the next match.

section.title: Search Forward
section.p: Begin searching the scrollback buffer in the forward direction for a string

section.title: Go to Bookmark
section.p: Go to bookmark 0..9 in the scrollback buffer

section.title: Go to line
section.p: Go to a specific line in the scrollback buffer.

section.title: Disconnect
section.p: Disconnect from the remote host (hangup phone if its a modem connection).

section.title: Hold Screen
section.p: Pauses or unpauses the the data input.

section.title: Home Screen
section.p: Roll screen to the beginning of the scrollback buffer

section.title: IBM 31xx Cancel
section.p: Sends: \{27} W\{3} (note the space before the 'W')

section.title: Ignore Keystroke
section.p: Does not send anything to the remote host, or perform an action. Does nothing.

section.title: Toggle Emacs Keyboard Mode
section.p: Enables or Disables the Emacs Special Keyboard Mode

section.title: Turn off Keyboard Mode
section.p: Turns off any active Special Keyboard Mode

section.title: Toggle Hebrew Keyboard Mode
section.p: Enables or Disables the Hebrew Special Keyboard Mode

section.title: Toggle Russian Keyboard Mode
section.p: Enables or Disables the Russian Special Keyboard Mode

section.title: Toggle WordPerfect Keyboard Mode
section.p: Enables or Disable the WordPerfect Special Keyboard Mode

section.title: DEC Keypad 0
section.p: If the keypad is in Normal (Numeric) mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE NUMERIC), then the digit 0 is sent.
If the keypad is in Application mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE APPLICATION) and the current terminal type is not one of those below, then \{27}?p is sent

section.title: DEC Keypad 1
section.p: If the keypad is in Normal (Numeric) mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE NUMERIC), then the digit 1 is sent.
If the keypad is in Application mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE APPLICATION) and the current terminal type is not one of those below, then \{27}?q is sent

section.title: DEC Keypad 2
section.p: If the keypad is in Normal (Numeric) mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE NUMERIC), then the digit 2 is sent.
If the keypad is in Application mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE APPLICATION) and the current terminal type is not one of those below, then \{27}?r is sent

section.title: DEC Keypad 3
section.p: If the keypad is in Normal (Numeric) mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE NUMERIC), then the digit 3 is sent.
If the keypad is in Application mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE APPLICATION) and the current terminal type is not one of those below, then \{27}?s is sent

section.title: DEC Keypad 4
section.p: If the keypad is in Normal (Numeric) mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE NUMERIC), then the digit 4 is sent.
If the keypad is in Application mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE APPLICATION) and the current terminal type is not one of those below, then \{27}?t is sent

section.title: DEC Keypad 5
section.p: If the keypad is in Normal (Numeric) mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE NUMERIC), then the digit 5 is sent.
If the keypad is in Application mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE APPLICATION) and the current terminal type is not one of those below, then \{27}?u is sent

section.title: DEC Keypad 6
section.p: If the keypad is in Normal (Numeric) mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE NUMERIC), then the digit 6 is sent.
If the keypad is in Application mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE APPLICATION) and the current terminal type is not one of those below, then \{27}?v is sent

section.title: DEC Keypad 7
section.p: If the keypad is in Normal (Numeric) mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE NUMERIC), then the digit 7 is sent.
If the keypad is in Application mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE APPLICATION) and the current terminal type is not one of those below, then \{27}?w is sent

section.title: DEC Keypad 8
section.p: If the keypad is in Normal (Numeric) mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE NUMERIC), then the digit 8 is sent.
If the keypad is in Application mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE APPLICATION) and the current terminal type is not one of those below, then \{27}?x is sent

section.title: DEC Keypad 9
section.p: If the keypad is in Normal (Numeric) mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE NUMERIC), then the digit 9 is sent.
If the keypad is in Application mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE APPLICATION) and the current terminal type is not one of those below, then \{27}?y is sent

section.title: DEC Keypad Comma
section.p: If the keypad is in Normal (Numeric) mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE NUMERIC), then the character ',' is sent.
If the keypad is in Application mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE APPLICATION) and the current terminal type is not one of those below, then \{27}?l is sent

section.title: DEC Keypad Decimal
section.p: If the keypad is in Normal (Numeric) mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE NUMERIC), then the character '.' is sent.
If the keypad is in Application mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE APPLICATION) and the current terminal type is not one of those below, then \{27}?n is sent

section.title: DEC Keypad Enter
section.p: If the keypad is in Normal (Numeric) mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE NUMERIC), then \{13} (CR) is sent, followed by \{10} (CR) if newline mode is enabled (SET TERM NEWLINE-MODE).
If the keypad is in Application mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE APPLICATION) and the current terminal type is not one of those below, then \{27}?M is sent

section.title: DEC Keypad Subtract
section.p: If the keypad is in Normal (Numeric) mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE NUMERIC), then the character '-' is sent.
If the keypad is in Application mode (SET TERM KEYPAD-MODE APPLICATION) and the current terminal type is not one of those below, then \{27}?m is sent

section.title: Scroll to Left Side
section.p: Console Version Only: Scroll all the way to the left side

section.title: Left Arrow
section.p: If the current terminal type is NOT one of those specially indicated below, K95 sends: \{27}D
Sends one of the following (can be changed via udfkeys):
Sends BS: \{8} (can be changed via udfkeys)
Sends BS: \{8} (can be changed via udfkeys)
Sends one of the following depending on the SET TERM ARROW setting

section.title: Scroll Left One Column
section.p: Console Version Only: Scroll left one column

section.title: Scroll left one page
section.p: Console Version Only: Scroll left one page (8 columns)

section.title: Cancel Mark Mode
section.p: Cancels mark mode without copying anything

section.title: Copy to Clipboard
section.p: Copies marked text to the clipboard

section.title: Copy to Host
section.p: Sends marked text to the host

section.title: Start mark mode
section.p: First one enters mark mode allowing you to position the cursor, second begins marking text from the cursor position.

section.title: Paste from Clipboard
section.p: Sends the text on the clipboard

section.title: Print FF
section.p: Sends the Form Feed character (\{12}) to the printer

section.title: Toggle Autoprint
section.p: Turns Autoprint on or off. When on, each line is sent to the printer.

section.title: Quit
section.p: Disconnect from host and terminate Kermit 95 without prompting.

section.title: Scroll Right
section.p: Console Version Only: Scroll all the way to the right

section.title: Right Arrow
section.p: If the current terminal type is NOT one of those specially indicated below, K95 sends: \{27}C
Sends one of the following (can be changed via udfkeys):
Sends NL: \{12} (can be changed via udfkeys)
Sends FF: \{12} (can be changed via udfkeys)
Sends one of the following depending on the SET TERM ARROW setting

section.title: Scroll Right One Column
section.p: Console Version Only: Scroll right one column

section.title: Scroll Right One Page
section.p: Console Version Only: Scroll right one page (8 columns)

section.title: Toggle status line
section.p: Switch status line between None, Indicator and Host-Writable

section.title: Switch Terminal Type
section.p: Switches to the next terminal type in the list

section.title: DEC UDK Do
section.p: Sends nothing until programmed via DECUDK

section.p: Sends nothing until programmed via DECUDK

section.title: Up Arrow
section.p: If the current terminal type is NOT one of those specially indicated below, K95 sends: \{27}A
Sends one of the following (can be changed via udfkeys):
Sends VT: \{11} (can be changed via udfkeys)
Sends VT: \{11} (can be changed via udfkeys)
Sends one of the following depending on the SET TERM ARROW setting

section.title: Scroll up one line
section.p: Scroll the screen up one line

section.title: PCTerm Keyboard Mode
section.p: In Kermit 95s normal keyboard modes described in the previous sections, pressing a key either sends ASCII-encoded text and control codes to the remote host, or performs some action within Kermit 95. Pressing the 'a' key sends ASCII character 97 ('a') to the remote host, pressing the left arow key sends ASCII characters 27 91 68 (ESC [ D) for VT-style terminals, etc.
The PCTerm keyboard mode does not work this way at all.

In the PCTerm keyboard mode, except for Ctrl+Capslock (which toggles PCTerm mode), Kermit 95 sends whatever keyboard hardware scan codes it receives from Windows straight to the remote host unmodified. The remote host receives a scan code on key down, and another on key up. As the scan codes are 8-bit values, this only works on 8-bit clean connections. PCTerm is available for any terminal type, but the remote host must understand PCTerm mode for it to work. PCTerm mode is not available on OS/2 as Kermit 95 is unable to receive key-up events from the OS/2 console.

For example, in PCTerm mode when you press down the A key on a regular US-English PC Keyboard, Kermit sends the byte 0x1E. And when the A key is released, Kermit sends the byte 0x9E. While the A key is held down, the byte 0x1E will be sent according to the key repeat rate. So holding A for a few moments may result in the bytes 0x1E 0x1E 0x1E 0x9E being sent.
This applies if multiple keys are pressed and released too. For example, if you press down A, then B, then release A then release B the bytes 0x1E 0x30 0x9E 0xB0 would be sent.
